Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the impact of right-to-work laws on the infant mortality rate by stating that it is 15 percent higher in states with such laws.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or support to back up the assertion that the infant mortality rate is directly influenced by right-to-work laws.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes a causal relationship between right-to-work laws and the infant mortality rate without considering other factors that may contribute to the disparity.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations or factors that may contribute to the difference in infant mortality rates between right-to-work states and non-right-to-work states.
